Codeforces Round 1037 (Div. 3) Editorial
By soullless, history, 5 months ago,

2126A - Only One Digit

Idea: soullless

Tutorial

2126A - Only One Digit

Key idea The minimal valid y is always a single digit. Simply find the smallest digit d∈0…9 that appears in the decimal representation of x; set y=d. Any multi-digit number would start with some digit already checked, so scanning beyond 9 is pointless.

What to do

- Build the set of digits occurring in x.

- Iterate through digits   → 9; the first one that belongs to the set is the answer.

Solution
#include <bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;
int main() {
  int t;
  cin >> t;
  while(t--) {
    int x;
    cin >> x;
    int mn = 9;
    while(x > 0) {
      mn = min(mn, x % 10);
      x/=10;
    }
    cout << mn << endl;
  }
}

2126B - No Casino in the Mountains

Idea: soullless

Tutorial

2126B - No Casino in the Mountains

Key observation

Inside one block of length len (all zeros) we must place patterns of k good days (the hike) plus one mandatory rest day after each hike except the last. Thus each hike consumes k + 1 slots, except the final one, which does not need a trailing rest day.

Therefore, the maximum number of hikes in one block is

hikes_in_block = ⌊(len+1)(k+1)⌋

Intuition: add an imaginary rest day to the end of the block, then just cut the segment into chunks of size k + 1.

Solution
#include <bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;
int main() {
  int t;
  cin >> t;
  while(t--) {
    int n,k;
    cin >> n >> k;
    int a[n + 1];
    for(int i = 1;i <= n;i++) cin >> a[i];
    int ans = 0;
    int cnt = 0;
    for(int i = 1;i <= n;i++) {
      if(a[i] == 1) {
        ans+=(cnt + 1)/(k + 1);
        cnt = 0;
        continue;
      }
      else {
        cnt++;
      }
    }
    ans+=(cnt + 1)/(k + 1);
    cout << ans << endl;
  }
}

2126C - I Will Definitely Make It

Idea: soullless

Tutorial

2126C - I Will Definitely Make It

Key idea While you stand on a tower of height h, you must depart no later than time h−1 (water hits level h at that instant). Therefore, if you arrive at height h at global time t, you have a slack of

slack=h−1−t

A move to a taller tower H costs H−h seconds. Feasibility condition:

t+(H−h)≤h−1 ⇔ t+(H−h)<h Greedy path (monotone-ascending) Any detour to a lower tower only wastes time and shrinks slack, so an optimal route is strictly non-decreasing in height. Thus:

1. Collect all tower heights, mark your start height h0.

2. Sort the heights ascending.

3. Starting with time=0, cur=h0, walk through every height H>cur in order:

- time+=H−cur (teleport duration)

- if time≥cur ⇒ drowned ⇒ answer NO

- else cur=H and continue.

4. If the loop finishes (or you began on the highest tower), output YES

Correctness sketch For each step we enforce time<cur, exactly the survival requirement for the tower we are leaving. Because total time accumulated along an ascending chain equals the direct height difference (Hmax−h0), any other path cannot finish earlier. Hence the greedy check is both necessary and sufficient.

Solution
#include <bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;
int main() {
  int t;
  cin >> t;
  while(t--) {
    int n,p;
    cin >> n >> p;
    int a[n + 1];
    for(int i = 1;i <= n;i++) cin >> a[i];
    int cur = a[p];
    int dist = a[p];
    sort(a + 1,a + n + 1);
    bool ans = true;
    for(int i = 1;i <= n;i++) {
      if(a[i] < cur) continue;
      if(a[i] &mdash; cur > dist) {
        ans = false;
      }
      cur = a[i];
    }
    if(ans) cout << "YES" << endl;
    else cout << "NO" << endl;
  }
}

2126D - This Is the Last Time

Idea: soullless

Tutorial

2126D - This Is the Last Time

Core insight The process is monotone non-decreasing: coins never drop after a visit (reali≥li). Hence we can repeatedly grab any casino whose interval currently covers c; doing so can only enlarge the set of playable casinos.

To obtain the best final value, whenever multiple casinos are currently available, choose the one with the largest reali−−−it gives the greatest immediate boost and cannot harm future options.

Greedy algorithm with a heap

1. Sort casinos by li asc.

2. Maintain an index ptr over the sorted list and a max-heap (priority queue) keyed by reali.

3. Let cur=k.

4. Loop

- Push into the heap every casino with li≤cur (advance ptr while that holds).

- Pop from the heap until you find one with cur≤ri (still covers current coins).

- If none exists ⇒ no more moves, stop.

- Otherwise set cur = reali and continue.

5. Output cur.

Because each casino enters the heap once and leaves once, the complexity is O(nlogn) per test case, O(n) memory

Correctness sketch Choice of maximal reali: suppose we pick a smaller real. The larger one remains playable now (it covers cur) and yields a≥ increase, so delaying it cannot enlarge the reachable set; taking it immediately is never worse.

The heap loop simulates exactly the greedy sequence above, terminating only when no playable casino remains — then cur is provably maximal.

Solution
#include <bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;
int main() {
  int t;
  cin >> t;
  while(t--) {
    int n,k;
    cin >> n >> k;
    pair <int,pair <int,int> > p[n + 1];
    for(int i = 1;i <= n;i++) cin >> p[i].first >> p[ыi].second.first >> p[i].second.second;
    sort(p + 1,p + n + 1);
    int cur = k;
    for(int i = 1;i <= n;i++) {
      if(p[i].first > cur) break;
      cur = max(cur,p[i].second.second);
    }
    cout << cur << endl;
  }
}

2126E - G-C-D, Unlucky!

Idea: Away_in_the_heavens

Tutorial

2126E - G-C-D, Unlucky!

Problem. We are given two integer arrays p[1…n] and s[1…n]. They are alleged to be the prefix-GCDs and suffix-GCDs of some hidden array a[1…n]:

pi = gcd(a1,...,ai), si = gcd(ai,...,an).

Decide whether such an array a exists.

Step 1. Immediate divisibility checks. For any prefix GCD chain one always has pi | pi−1 (moving right never introduces new prime factors). Likewise, for the suffix chain si | si+1. So we must have

pi−1 mod pi=0 for every i ≥ 2, si+1 mod si=0 for every i ≤ n − 1.

Both chains describe the GCD of the entire array when they meet in the middle, therefore pn must equal s1. Denote that common value by g. If any of these conditions fails, the answer is immediately "NO".

Step 2. Factor g out. Write Pi=pig and Si=sig. From now on we only reason about the reduced chains P and S; g can be multiplied back into every ai at the end.

Step 3. What must hold at a single position i. Suppose we already know gcd(a1,…,ai−1)=pi−1 and gcd(ai+1,…,an)=si+1. We must choose a positive integer A such that

gcd(pi−1,A)=pi and gcd(A,si+1)=si.

Divide by g everywhere and let

x=pi−1pi (an integer ≥ 1), y=si+1si (also ≥ 1).

The two equations become

gcd(x,Ag)=1 and gcd(Ag,y)=1, Pi divides Ag, Si divides Ag.

Set Ag=u. We need a u that is a common multiple of Pi and Si and is simultaneously coprime to both x and y.

Key arithmetic facts: Pi and x are always coprime, because x=Pi−1Pi and no prime can divide both a number and its own quotient. Symmetrically, Si and y are coprime.

Therefore u=Pi ∗ Si works iff

gcd(x,Si)=1 and gcd(y,Pi)=1.

These two gcd tests are both necessary and sufficient; if they pass we can put ai=g ∗ Pi ∗ Si.

Step 4. Global algorithm.

1. Verify the divisibility chains and pn=s1; if something fails, print NO.

2. For every i=2…n check gcd((pi−1pi),Si)=1.

3. For every i=n−1…1 check gcd((si+1si),Pi)=1. (All divisions are exact by the chain property.)

4. If every test passes, print YES; otherwise NO.

Step 5. Complexity. Each gcd call is logarithmic in the values involved; we make O(n) such calls and a constant number of simple passes over the arrays, so the total running time per test case is O(n log maxvalue) with O(1) extra memory.

If the algorithm answers YES, one explicit witness array is ai=g ∗ Pi ∗ Si.

Solution
#include <bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;
main() {
    int t;
    cin >> t;
    while (t--) {
        int n;
        cin >> n;
        long long a[n + 1];
        for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
            cin >> a[i];
        }
        long long b[n + 1];
        for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
            cin >> b[i];
        }
        long long ans[n + 1];
        for (int i = n; i >= 1; i--) {
            ans[i] = lcm(a[i], b[i]);
        }
        bool ch = 1;
        if(ans[1] != a[1]) ch = 0;
        if(ans[n] != b[n]) ch = 0;
        for (int i = 2; i <= n; i++) {
            if (__gcd(a[i &mdash; 1], ans[i]) != a[i]) {
                ch = 0;
            }
        }
        for (int i = n &mdash; 1; i >= 1; i--) {
            if (__gcd(b[i + 1], ans[i]) != b[i]) {
                ch = 0;
            }
        }
        if (ch) {
            cout << "YES" << "\n";
        } else {
            cout << "NO" << "\n";
        }
    }
}

2126F - 1-1-1, Free Tree!

Idea: soullless

Tutorial

2126F - 1-1-1, Free Tree!

Root the tree at vertex 1. During one DFS store, for every vertex v, its parent parv and the weight costv of the edge (parv, v). While visiting a child u of v, also add costu to a dictionary memvcolour under key au; thus memvc is the total weight of edges from v to children that currently have colour c. The DFS finishes in O(n).

Compute the initial answer ans−−−thesumofcostsofedgeswhoseendpointshavedifferentcolours. Walk over all vertices v ≠ 1 and, if av differs from aparv, add costv to ans. This is O(n).

A query gives a vertex v and a new colour x. Let old=av. First handle the edges from v to its children. All those edges whose children had colour old were previously free; after the repaint they become paid, so add mem_{v_{old}} to ans. Conversely, the edges counted in memvx were previously paid and now become free, so subtract memvx from ans.

Next handle the edge (parv, v) if v is not the root. Its weight w=costv was included in ans exactly when old differed from the parent's colour; if so, subtract w. After the repaint the edge must be included exactly when x differs from the parent's colour; if so, add w. After that update the parent's dictionary: decrease memparvold by w and increase memparvx by w.

Write av=x and output the new ans. Every dictionary access is an O(log degv) map operation, so each query costs O(log n) in the worst case. Overall complexity for one test case is O((n + q) log n) time and O(n) memory, which fits easily in the limits.

Solution
#include <bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;
const int B = 2e5 + 100;
int n;
int col[B];
long long costt = 0;
vector <pair <int,int> > reb[B];
bool was[B];
map <int,long long> cnt[B];
int pred[B];
long long zn[B];
void dfs(int v) {
  was[v] = true;
  for(auto u:reb[v]) {
    if(was[u.first]) {
      pred[v] = u.first;
      continue;
    }
    if(col[v] != col[u.first]) costt+=u.second;
    dfs(u.first);
    zn[u.first] = u.second;
    cnt[v][col[u.first]]+=zn[u.first];
  }
}
void update(int v,int x) {
  if(v != 1) {
    cnt[pred[v]][col[v]]-=zn[v];
    if(col[pred[v]] == col[v]) costt+=zn[v];
    cnt[pred[v]][x]+=zn[v];
    if(col[pred[v]] == x) costt-=zn[v];
  }
  else {
      
  }
  costt+=cnt[v][col[v]];
  costt-=cnt[v][x];
  col[v] = x;
}
void clr() {
  for(int i = 1;i <= n;i++) {
    reb[i].clear();
    was[i] = false;
    cnt[i].clear();
    zn[i] = 0;
  }
  costt = 0;
}
int main() {
  int t;
  cin >> t;
  while(t--) {
    int q;
    cin >> n >> q;
    for(int i = 1; i <= n; i++) cin >> col[i];
    for(int i = 1; i < n; i++) {
      int u, v, c;
      cin >> u >> v >> c;
      reb[v].push_back({u,c});
      reb[u].push_back({v,c});
    }
    dfs(1);
    while(q--) {
      int pos,x;
      cin >> pos >> x;
      update(pos,x);
      cout << costt << "\n";
    }
    clr();
  }
}

2126G1 - Big Wins! (easy version)

Idea: soullless

Tutorial

2126G1 - Big Wins! (easy version)

The array values do not exceed 100, so the median we are hunting for can be any integer m from 1 to 100.

For a fixed m mark every position j by

bj=+1 if aj≥m

bj=−1 otherwise.

For any subarray its median is at least m ⇔ the majority of its elements are ≥ m ⇔ the sum of the b's on that segment is positive. Let prefk = ∑ki=1b[i]. Then a subarray (l, r] has positive sum iff prefr>prefl.

For the same fixed m we would like to know, for every position j, whether there is a positive - sum subarray that contains j. That is true whenever min0≤l<jprefl<prefj   or   prefj−1<maxj≤r≤nprefr. Pre-compute left-side prefix minima prefmnj=min(pref0≤x≤j) and right-side suffix maxima suffmxj=max(prefj≤x≤n) in two linear passes.

If either inequality holds, index j can lie in some subarray whose median is ≥ m. We are free to take that same j as the minimum of the chosen subarray, giving value aj. Hence, for that j we can realise the gap m−aj. Among all indices that satisfy the test keep the largest difference.

Repeat the whole procedure for m=1…100 and output the global maximum. Every round over m costs O(n): build b[], prefix sums, prefix minima, suffix maxima, then scan once more. Total work O(100n)≤ 2 ⋅ 10⁷ for n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10⁵, which fits easily. Memory is O(n).

Solution
#include <bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;
const int B = 2e5 + 100;

int main() {
  int t;
  cin >> t;
  while(t--) {
    int n;
    cin >> n;
    int a[n + 1];
    for(int i = 1;i <= n;i++) cin >> a[i];
    int ans = 0;
    for(int i = 1;i <= 100;i++) {
      int b[n + 1] = {};
      for(int j = 1;j <= n;j++) {
        if(a[j] >= i) b[j] = 1;
        else b[j] = -1;
      }
      int pref[n + 1] = {};
      for(int j = 1; j <= n; j++) {
        pref[j] = pref[j - 1] + b[j]; 
      }
      int prefmn[n + 2] = {},suffmx[n + 1] = {};
      prefmn[0] = 0,suffmx[n] = pref[n];
      for(int j = 1; j <= n; j++) {
        prefmn[j] = min(prefmn[j - 1],pref[j]);
      }
      for(int j = n - 1; j >= 1; j--) {
        suffmx[j] = max(suffmx[j + 1],pref[j]);
      }
      for(int j = 1; j <= n; j++) {
        if(prefmn[j - 1] <= pref[j] || pref[j - 1] <= suffmx[j]) {
          ans = max(ans,i - a[j]);
        }
      }
    } 
    cout << ans << endl;
  }
}

2126G2 - Big Wins! (hard version)

Idea: soullless

Tutorial

2126G2 - Big Wins! (hard version)

Goal: maximise  median(subarray) − minimum(subarray). Treat the minimum as the "left pointer" mn that we increase from 1 up to max ai. For every fixed mn we try to push a second pointer med (the candidate median) as high as possible while some subarray exists whose minimum is exactly mn and whose median is at least med. The answer is the largest difference med − mn reached during this sweep.

Fix a value mn. Any subarray whose minimum equals mn must contain at least one position u with au = mn, and the whole subarray must lie inside the maximal span where that u is the strict minimum. Those spans are computed once by the usual monotone stack: lu= first index to the left that has value< a[u]+ 1, ru=first index to the right that has value< au− 1.

For a potential median M define an array signi = +1 if ai ≥ M, −1 otherwise. Inside any interval its median is ≥ M exactly when the total sum of sign over that interval is positive (at least half the elements are high). Therefore, for a particular position u to serve as the minimum we need

maxSuffix(lu, u−1)+signu+maxPrefix(u+1, ru)≥ 0.

Here maxSuffix and maxPrefix are, respectively, the largest suffix sum ending at u−1 and the largest prefix sum starting at u+1, measured in the sign array.

All max-prefix / max-suffix / total-sum queries can be answered in O(log n) with a segment-tree that stores at each node (ans,bestPrefix,bestSuffix,totalSum). Merging two children follows the standard Kadane-style formulas.

Algorithm loop. Initialise the segment tree with sign ≡ +1, so total sum everywhere is positive; set med = 1. For med←1 we must exclude from the tree every position whose value is < med, by updating that point to −1. Now iterate mn from 1 upward:

- for every index u with au = mn evaluate the inequality above.

- while the inequality is satisfied for all such indices, increment med by 1 and for every position whose value just became < med perform one point-update to −1 in the segment tree.

- when the test fails for some u, stop raising med.

- record ans=max(ans,med − mn).

Because med only increases and never exceeds n, the total number of tree updates is O(n) and every update / query costs O(log n), so the whole run is O(n log n). Memory is O(n).

Why correct. For each mn the inner while moves med upward greedily until the moment no subarray with minimum mn can keep the median≥ med; thus the last valid value of med realises the true maximum for this mn. The outer sweep examines every possible minimum, hence the largest gap ever recorded is the global optimum.

Solution
#include<bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;
int n;
int a[200005 + 2];
array<int, 4> t[800005];
array<int, 4> merge(array<int, 4>a, array<int, 4>b) {
    int ans = max(a[0], b[0]);
    int mxpref = max(a[1], a[3] + b[1]);
    int mxsuff = max(b[2], a[2] + b[3]);
    ans = max({ans, mxpref, mxsuff});
    int sum = a[3] + b[3];
    return {ans, mxpref, mxsuff, sum};
}
void update(int v, int tl, int tr, int pos, int val) {
    if (tl == tr) {
        t[v] = {max(val, 0), max(val, 0), max(val, 0), val};
    } else {
        int tm = (tl + tr) >> 1;
        if (pos <= tm) {
            update(v * 2, tl, tm, pos, val);
        } else {
            update(v * 2 + 1, tm + 1, tr, pos, val);
        }
        t[v] = merge(t[v * 2], t[v * 2 + 1]);
    }
}
array<int, 4> get(int v, int tl, int tr, int l, int r) {
    if (tl == l && tr == r) {
        return t[v];
    } else if (l > r) {
        return {0, 0, 0, 0};
    } else {
        int tm = (tl + tr) >> 1;
        return merge(get(v * 2, tl, tm, l, min(r, tm)), get(v * 2 + 1, tm + 1, tr, max(l, tm + 1), r));
    }
}
int solve(int n, vector<int>A) {
    int m = 0;
    for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
        a[i] = A[i &mdash; 1];
        m = max(m, a[i]);
    }
    vector<int>ind[m + 1];
    for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
        ind[a[i]].push_back(i);
    }
    stack<int>s;
    s.push(0);
    a[0] = -INT_MAX;
    int l[n + 1];
    for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
        while (a[s.top()] >= a[i]) {
            s.pop();
        }
        l[i] = s.top() + 1;
        s.push(i);
    }
    a[n + 1] = -INT_MAX;
    s.push(n + 1);
    int r[n + 1];
    for (int i = n; i >= 1; i--) {
        while (a[s.top()] >= a[i]) {
            s.pop();
        }
        r[i] = s.top() &mdash; 1;
        s.push(i);
    }
    int med = 1;
    for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
        update(1, 1, n, i, 1);
    }
    for (auto u : ind[1]) {
        update(1, 1, n, u, -1);
    }
    int ans = 0;
    for (int mn = 1; mn <= m; mn++) {
        for (auto u : ind[mn]) {
            int lg = l[u], rg = r[u];
            while (med < m && get(1, 1, n, lg, u &mdash; 1)[2] + get(1, 1, n, u + 1, rg)[1] + (a[u] < (med) ? -1 : 1) >= 0) {
                med++;
                for (auto u : ind[med]) {
                    update(1, 1, n, u, -1);
                }
            }
        }
        // cout << med << ' ' << mn << endl;
        ans = max(ans, med &mdash; mn);
    }
    return ans;
}
int solveslow(int n, vector<int>A) {
    for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
        a[i] = A[i &mdash; 1];
    }
    int mx = 0;
    for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
        vector<int>v;
        for (int j = i; j <= n; j++) {
            v.push_back(a[j]);
            sort(v.begin(), v.end());
            mx = max(mx, v[v.size() / 2] &mdash; v[0]);
        }
    }
    return mx;
}
int rnd() {
    return (rand() + rand() * RAND_MAX);
}
main() {
    ios_base::sync_with_stdio(false);
    cin.tie(0);
    int tt;
    cin >> tt;
    while(tt--) {
        int n;
        cin >> n;
        vector<int>v;
        for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
            int x;
            cin >> x;
            v.push_back(x);
        }
        cout << solve(n, v) << endl;
        // cout << solveslow(n, v) << endl;
        for(int i = 0;i <= n*4;i++) {
            t[i][0] = 0;
            t[i][1] = 0;
            t[i][2] = 0;
            t[i][3] = 0;
        }
    }
}

    +8

    because lets say for some m, you found a valid segment (l, r] It may be possible that m doesn't lie in that segment or some value greater than m might become the median. In the above mentioned cases, when you eventually move to larger values of m, the range sum for the same subarray will still be non-negative! (edit: In that case, the answer is BOUND to be greater than the currently computed value)

    see this case:

    lets only operate on index i=0

    arr[] = {1, 3, 3, 4}

    • for m = 1 and i = 0

    b = [1, 1, 1, 1] Since a valid range exists, my answer will be updated to ans = m - a[0] = 1 - 1 = 0

    • for m = 2 and i = 0

    b = [-1, 1, 1, 1] Valid range exists for i = 0, so ans = m - a[0] = 2 - 1 = 1

    • for m = 3 and i = 0

    b = [-1, 1, 1, 1] Valid range exists for i = 0, so ans = m - a[0] = 3 - 1 = 2

    • for m = 4 and i = 0

    b = [-1, -1, -1, 1] It's pretty clear that no valid subarray exists for i = 0

    so my final answer become 2, hope this helps..

          I mean that we can use the interval tree to visit all intervals overlapping the current number of coins, kk, and erase them from the tree (as they do not need to be visited again). The next iteration of BFS uses the values of kk that have been reached, until there are no more intervals left. In other words, the graph would be implicit.

          Since intervals are sparse, we can store them in center-based tree with 2n2n nodes. Each possible value of kk would perform a O(logn)O(log⁡n) operation on the tree, possibly visiting some number of intervals that would be removed, so the overall time complexity would be O(nlogn)O(nlog⁡n). But perhaps there are more elegant solutions to this problem.

        We can use a segment tree instead. Let's sort intervals by their left ends. Node responsible for an interval [l,r] contains a pair {maxR,ind}, where maxR is a maximum right end of intervals in range [l,r], ind is an index where this maximum was reached.

+3

Alternative solution for FF (which I've seen quite a few times and are probably the reason for all the hacks):

Let's fix some XX. For all vertices uu with deg(u)≤Xdeg(u)≤X, we can just simulate the change and recalculate the answer in O(X)O(X). If deg(u)>Xdeg(u)>X, for all adjacent colors, we will store the sum of edges with that specific color that end in uu. A color-update of such vertices can be performed in O(1)O(1) (add the contribution of the old color, remove the contribution of the new color).

It remains to update this "color-map". Since each vertex vv can be adjacent to at most nXnX such vertices, these updates can also be performed in O(n/X)O(n/X) time.

The total time complexity is O(n+q⋅max(X,n/X))O(n+q⋅max(X,n/X)). The memory complexity is O(n+nX⋅n)O(n+nX⋅n) if we remove the unused colors from the map.

If we choose X=n−−√X=n, the total time complexity is O((n+q)n−−√)O((n+q)n). Unfortunately, my solution with that choice of XX was hacked (MLE), but setting XX to 35003500 ( 5n−−√ 5n) works.

Looks like there were many solutions for G2G2, here's mine using Persistent Segment Trees and maximum subarray sum queries (somewhat similar to the editorial but worse time complexity xd). (This segtree extension was also part of the solution of a recent div 3H).

The general idea is to fix the index i∈[1,n]i∈[1,n] of the minimum element and find the largest possible median containing ii. We can binary search the median with the same construction of the array b(m)b(m) as in the editorial of G1G1, i.e. for some fixed mm, bj(m)=aj≥m ? 1:−1bj(m)=aj≥m ? 1:−1. Any non-negative subarray sum would correspond to a median ≥m≥m. To ensure that ii is included in that subarray, we add a large number to bi(m)bi(m), i.e. bi(m)=X+(ai≥m ? 1:−1)bi(m)=X+(ai≥m ? 1:−1). One option would be X=2nX=2n.

We need all the possible arrays of b(m)b(m), which can be stored in a persistent segment tree. Start with bj=−1bj=−1 and for all v∈[1,n]v∈[1,n] in descending order, do the following:

  • For all indices ii with ai=vai=v, set bi(v)=1bi(v)=1.

After doing that for all indices with value vv (and values >v>v), our persistent segment tree will have the values of b(v)b(v).

While iterating over the ii and doing the binary search, we need to add 2n2n to bibi. This is easy, since we can simply update bibi and "forget" about the update.

The total time complexity is O(n⋅log2(n))O(n⋅log2⁡(n)), where the loglog factors come from binary search and persistent segment tree update. The memory complexity is around O(n⋅logn)O(n⋅log⁡n), but this has a high constant hidden, since we need to store 4 ints in each vertex of our segment tree for the queries. It is important that we remove the persistent segment tree vertices we create while querying — otherwise, we will need quite a lot of memory ...

Submission

    I came up with another proof. Hope this might help.

    Theorem. If the prefix and suffix gcd sequences p1:np1:n and s1:ns1:n are valid (i.e., there exists an original sequence whose prefix and suffix gcd sequences are p1:np1:n and s1:ns1:n), then sequence a1:na1:n, defined by ak=lcm(pk,sk)=pkskgcd(pk,sk)ak=lcm(pk,sk)=pkskgcd(pk,sk), has a prefix gcd sequence of p1:np1:n and a suffix gcd sequence of s1:ns1:n.

    Proof: First, we can prove gcd(a1)=a1=p1gcd(a1)=a1=p1 easily using the fact that gcd(p1,s1)=s1gcd(p1,s1)=s1.

    Then, we can prove the rest with mathematical induction. Assume that gcd(a1:k−1)=pk−1gcd(a1:k−1)=pk−1, we want to prove gcd(a1:k)=pkgcd(a1:k)=pk.

    gcd(a1:k)=gcd(pk−1,ak)=gcd(pk−1,pkskgcd(pk,sk))gcd(a1:k)=gcd(pk−1,ak)=gcd(pk−1,pkskgcd(pk,sk))

    Therefore, proving gcd(a1:k)=pkgcd(a1:k)=pk is equivalent to proving pk−1pkpk−1pk and skgcd(pk,sk)skgcd(pk,sk) are coprime.

    Given the validity of p1:np1:n and s1:ns1:n, there exists an original sequence b1:nb1:n such that they are its prefix and suffix gcd sequences. Then, we have:

    gcd(pk−1pk,skgcd(pk,sk))=gcd(gcd(b1:k−1)gcd(b1:k),gcd(bk:n)gcd(b1:k,bk:n))=gcd(gcd(b1:k−1)gcd(b1:k),gcd(bk:n)gcd(b1:n))gcd(pk−1pk,skgcd(pk,sk))=gcd(gcd(b1:k−1)gcd(b1:k),gcd(bk:n)gcd(b1:k,bk:n))=gcd(gcd(b1:k−1)gcd(b1:k),gcd(bk:n)gcd(b1:n))

    Because gcd(gcd(b1:k−1),gcd(bk:n))=gcd(b1:n)gcd(gcd(b1:k−1),gcd(bk:n))=gcd(b1:n), gcd(b1:k−1)gcd(b1:n)gcd(b1:k−1)gcd(b1:n) and gcd(bk:n)gcd(b1:n)gcd(bk:n)gcd(b1:n) are coprime, and therefore gcd(b1:k−1)gcd(b1:k)gcd(b1:k−1)gcd(b1:k) and gcd(bk:n)gcd(b1:n)gcd(bk:n)gcd(b1:n) are coprime, due to the fact that gcd(b1:n)|gcd(b1:k)gcd(b1:n)|gcd(b1:k).

    Now we have proven that the prefix gcd sequence of a1:na1:n is p1:np1:n, and the proof for the suffix gcd sequence is symmetric.

    Corollary. The prefix and suffix gcd sequences p1:np1:n and s1:ns1:n are valid, if and only if sequence a1:na1:n, defined by ak=lcm(pk,sk)=pkskgcd(pk,sk)ak=lcm(pk,sk)=pkskgcd(pk,sk), has a prefix gcd sequence of p1:np1:n and a suffix gcd sequence of s1:ns1:n.

    Proof: Trivial. Therefore, we can construct a1:na1:n and see if its prefix and suffix gcd sequence fit with p1:np1:n and s1:ns1:n to judge if they are valid.

        0

        Sorry for skipping the if and only if part, felt too tired and just slacked off lol.

        From the theorem, it is proven that if the prefix and suffix gcd sequences are valid, then our construction is a valid underlying sequence. But conversely, if the construction is a valid underlying sequence for the prefix and suffix gcd sequences, then it means that there exists an underlying sequence to have the given sequences as its prefix and suffix gcd sequences, which means that the prefix and suffix gcd sequences are valid, so it is an iff.

        The theorem is proving something like: if there exists a solution to the problem, then X is a solution to the problem. But conversely if X is a solution to the problem, then there exists a solution to the problem.

        As for the uniqueness of sequence b, it is just a device to show the properties of the sequences p and s, so I don't need it to be unique, I just need it to exist, which is assured by the definition of validity in the problem.

        0

        After much pondering over what you said, I decided to investigate what was really happening. I found that, in most implementations, the update function merges nodes 2i2i with 2i+12i+1 into node ii, which may not be the correct order for all ii when nn is not a power of 2. However, the query function follows a different pattern, so that problematic nodes will be skipped and correct order is preserved (even if the right pointer falls in a subtree to the left of that of the left pointer). Anyway, thanks for the reply!

Another DSU solution to problem G (inspired by jiangly's): 329775391

Explanation: for each aiai in descending order, search for the next available index jj, both to the left and to the right, such that it can be part of a good segment (according to the prefix/suffix sums of 11 and −1−1).

From my understanding, it works because each minimum need only be visited once (since we are iterating in descending order of median value and flipping values from −1−1 to 11). At each iteration, we need only visit two such indices. Hope this makes sense.

    what is the logic behind the increment/decrements? I get why DSU works here but struggling to understand how to actually implement it to solve this problem

    → Reply
    • »

      dsogari
      5 months ago, show #
      »
      »
      »
      dsogari
      5 months ago, hide # ^ |
      ← Rev. 2 →  
      0

      The DSU in this case works like a linked list where elements are indices, except that it can identify the next item from a given index (which a linked list cannot do natively). You start with all indices and repeatedly remove them. The increment/decrement is just a way to link an index to its left or right neighbor. (This is not to be confused with the ±1±1 used to model the problem.)

    0

    When I thought carefully about it, I also arrived at this conclusion. Initially, I didn't understand the editorial and even thought it might be incorrect. But after thinking it through, I believe the editorial can be interpreted this way:

    We only need to check whether a subarray ending (or starting) at position jj exists because — suppose both intervals [x,j][x,j] and [j,y][j,y] are invalid. What does that imply? It means that whether we extend to the left or to the right, in any such extended subarray, the number of elements greater than or equal to mm is less than half of the total number of elements. In this case, if we try to enlarge the interval from one end, the other end becomes a burden — it won’t help us make the number of elements ≥m≥m reach or exceed half.

    This is why the condition in the editorial — that the suffix maximum is greater than or equal to the prefix minimum — is equivalent to the requirement. That is, either the suffix maximum is at position jj, or the prefix minimum is at position jj; at least one of these must hold.

    From another perspective, a[j]a[j] is at worst −1−1. If extending in either direction from jj fails to make the sum greater than or equal to 00, then the best possible result we can achieve is just −1−1.

    → Reply
